thread.title: Heavy selling pushes Aust stocks lower
thread.title_full: Heavy selling pushes Aust stocks lower

title: Heavy selling pushes Aust stocks lower
text:
Wed, Sep 23, 2015, 11:04 AM AEST - Australia Markets close in 4 hrs 56 mins Heavy selling pushes Aust stocks lower AAP â€“ 14 minutes ago Print 
The Australian share market has opened more than one per cent lower following a negative lead from overseas and the ripple effect from the Volkswagen emissions scandal. 
There was heavy selling across all sectors on the ASX200 when the market opened on Wednesday, with resources giant BHP Billiton down 3.44 per cent at 1030 AEST and Rio Tinto 2.05 per cent lower. 
IG Markets analyst Angus Nicholson said BHP's confirmation that it was cutting capital and exploration expenditure by $US2.5 billion ($A3.53 billion) to $US8.5 billion this financial year did not factor into the drop. 
"There seems to be a real panic right now going on in the market but without any one smoking gun, perhaps except for the huge crash in VW stock price in Europe affecting other automakers and then industrials," Mr Nicholson said. 
"The amount of selling we're seeing in European markets and American markets and now coming over into Asia seems a bit overdone and I would be surprised if it did continue into tomorrow." 
Volkswagen this week admitted that 11 million of its diesel cars worldwide are equipped with devices that can cheat pollution tests, and is now subject to a criminal investigation in the US. 
Mr Nicholson said Chinese manufacturing data set for release at 1145 AEST could reverse some of the declines if the numbers improved as expected. 
BHP was down 82 cents at $23.04, with Rio Tinto down $1.01 at $48.18. Fortescue dropped 7.5 cents, or 3.92 per cent, to $1.84. 
The big four banks were also down, with Commonwealth losing $1.04, or 1.41 per cent, to $72.76, Westpac falling 45 cents, or 1.38 per cent, to $30.66, NAB dropping 35 cents, or 1.15 per cent, to $30.16 and ANZ shedding 31 cents, or 1.11 per cent, to $27.52. 
Nufarm was one of the only stocks to enjoy a positive morning, rising 61 cents, or 8.63 per cent, to $7.68 after the crop spray maker and seeds supplier lifted full year profit 15 per cent to $43.2 million. 
KEY FACTS 
* At 1030 AEST on Wednesday, the benchmark S&P/ASX200 index was down 65.1 points, or 1.28 per cent, at 5,038.5 points. 
* The broader All Ordinaries index was down 61.2 points, or 1.19 per cent, at 5,069.6 points. 
* The December share price index futures contract was down 76 points at 5,020 points, with 13,497 contracts traded. 
* National turnover was 296.9 million securities worth $649.8 million. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook
